newsitem.title: CHILE: Escondida says shipments unhurt by strike.
newsitem.headline: Escondida says shipments unhurt by strike.

text.p: Copper shipments from Chile's Escondida mine will continue as normal and are unaffected by a strike by some of its workers, the mine's CEO Ken Pickering said Wednesday.
"Production is fully normal and that means shipments are normal," Pickering was quoted as saying by a spokeswoman in a telephone interview with Reuters.
Striking workers began voting earlier Wednesday to decide whether to accept the firm's latest wage offer.
The mine's 350-odd unionized workers stopped work Friday to demand progress in wage negotiations. The rest of the mine's 2,000-strong workforce did not join the strike.
Mine CEO Ken Pickering said Monday that the strike had slown down operations slightly but that output of both concentrates and cathodes was normal.
The 800,000-tonne-a-year mine is owned by Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd and RTZ-CRA.
